text:
33cl bottle shared with 3 friends. About 18 months old. 
Thin off white head. Clear black pour. Quite malty

Bottle shared. Black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, dark chocolate, pine, resinous hops, roast and light citrus. Flavour is above moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with alcohol warmth and soft carbonation.

Rated from June 2015 from memory. This has to be my favorite in this style. Amazing citrus flavors. Hard to believe when you look at the dark color and then taste it. The roast flavor brings an interesting aspect to a very juicy IPA base. Wish this would be made again.

12 oz bottle picked up locally from notes. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malts, dark chocolate, tropical fruits, citrus, earthy notes, pine resin, floral character, the roasted malt is very mild unlike many black IPAs, solid drinking beer that might be my favorite so far.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a nice almost black, fully opaque body with a thick, three centimetre tall deep brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, PNW hops, caramel, light nuts, earth and a touch of smoked peat as well - not too fragrant, but noticeable with the malt more so than the hops. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong herbal and piney hops up front that give way to a torched malt flavour with a hint of smoke and earth really coming through, along with a earthy quality and some light mushroom flavours. Aftertaste is well balanced with the hops and the malt with quite a bit of earthiness and not much sweetness to speak of at all - perhaps a touch of caramel. Overall, a nice Black IPA with a pronounced malt note and some nice hop elements, but the body really isnt there and there isnt too much complexity aside from the smoke and peat flavours, but still good to sample - a top Black IPA - not so much (at least not now), but worth trying if you can find it. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Alexandria, Virginia on 05-July-2015 for US$2,99 sampled at home in Washington on 28-February-2016 on the Academy Award Night.

12/1/15. A group of us drank and discussed each beer while listening to the music that inspired them. We had a blast! 12oz bottle. So many Uranus jokes when this one was busted out. Dont believe me? Check out rdixon77s rating below mine. Black pour with a small tan head. Citrus hops and roasty, ashy malts on the aroma. Good flavor, ashy, coffee, citrus, floral. Not bad.
At drowlands amazing symphony listening planets tasting! So awesome! So many Uranus jokes, so little time. Ill stick with my recorded deScription of this one.Uranus isDeep, Dark, Delicious.

Brewed a half year earlier, and just received, this is a black side of the moon american strong ale. The pine, the hops, are in the finish (with a bit of mold on the lips in the aftertaste). Bottom line: very enjoyable black

Sample at the Far Out! Space Tasting #2 on 10/01/2015. Brown-black color with some ruby around the edges, and a medium khaki head that recedes gradually. Small patches of lace. Aroma of tropical fruit, piney hops and malt. Medium to full body with flavors of citrus, floral hops, pine and malt. The finish is malty up front with a resiny hops aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Pours barely translucent coffee brown with a tinge of ruby and a very thick and persistent tan head. Aroma presents fresh hop, toasted malt, and subtle chocolate notes. Flavor starts with resiny hops and expands into chocolate, molasses, malt, licorice and toffee. Bitterness and dark fruit tones provide support. Firm body supports firm fizz and a dark, hoppy finish. Magical indeed!

Bottle from Del Mesa, San Diego. Black beer with a nice beige head. Hoppy roasted aroma, caramel, grapes, pine, some chocolate. Hoppy chocolate and pine flavor, pine apples, licorice, peach, mango, some dark chocolate. Nicely balanced BIPA.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Porter Bar goblet. 24 May 2015 bottling date 

Appearance: the beer is a very dark, brownish-black color, with a small size, light tan head. 

Aroma: dark roasted malts with less hop presence than expected but some sweet tropical fruit and herbal notes, 

Flavor: rich and fairly strong mix of dark roasted malts and hops. Some tropical fruit notes, including pineapple, early on, followed by a bit of char and smoke, with faint earthy and peat tones. Moderately bitter.
Provided by TR in a growler from the brew pub. Absolutely delicious. Great complexity.

12 oz, bottled 5-25. Black with a slight white beige head. Aroma is floral and hay field. Taste is mild bitterness, floral hops. Some light dark malts, similar to what you would expect from a light Porter. Hops are a bit stale. My fault for not trying it fresher.
tap at cafe. hands down, best black IPA ive had. Complex yet amazing nose and flavor. killer!
I tried to think of all the juvenile "Uranus" jokes I could, but the best one was what my friend suggested: Thumbs up, Uranus.

12 ounce bottle. All the way from ND! Thanks Adam. Pours a dark brown color with a large light brown colored head. A big resiny hop nose, chocolate and ash. Very lovely beer; big balance, citrus, at times this is a citra bomb, chocolate, ashy, dark roast. Just lovely. The finish is all fresh hops and some vanilla. I could drink a liter and them immediately be blasted. The drinkabilty is just amazing.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Huge tropical fruit hop character, light chocolate, lingering bitterness, some a ashy astringency in the finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours nearly pitch black in color and topped with a small layer of tan colored foam that shows good retention. Sudsy lacing coats the glass all around. The aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, roast, black malt, citrus fruit, light stone fruit, and huge floral and pine notes from the hops. Definitely has some dank notes as well. The flavor follows with the stone fruit and citrus up front along with notes of dark chocolate, roast, and ample floral and pine hop bitterness on the back end. The bitter dark chocolate and roast meld perfectly with the citrus fruit and pine notes. Medium bodied and smooth with balanced carbonation that leads to a lengthy bitter sweet finish. This is a really well done black IPA. Good stuff.
Poured a medium brown with a beige head. Aroma was big tropical and citrusy hops, very light roast character. Flavor similar, alky held in check, very nicely balanced black ipa

From notes. Enjoyed at the brewpub on May 30. Pour is a medium black with ruby shining through the edges. There is a khaki colored head that keeps a film but leaves awesome lace. The aroma is nicely fruity with a hint of malt and an overload of dank hops. Light chocolate on the back end. The flavor is bitter and hoppy up front. There is a nice fruity character and a solid malt note on the back end. The mouth feel is a little light, but the carbonation is spot on, helping it stick around. The aftertaste is lingeringly bitter and malty. Really good imperial black IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - thanks Clownisseur! Pours clear black, medium tan head, dissipates slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is roasy, cocoa, pine. Flavor is light plus sweet, quite bitter, pine and roastiness. Medium body, sharp bitterness lingers. This is not my idea of a properly styled black IPA.

Pours super dark red with a khaki head. Head retention is good. AROMA: malty, herbal/floral hops, caramel, herbs, citrus, spruce bitterness, raisin, earthy, dark stone fruit, pineapple, spice, soy sauce, lightly roasted, little coffee bitterness, peppercorn, brown sugar, boozy and coriander. TASTE: dark stone fruit, hop spice, malt bitterness, slight salt, pine bitterness, caramel, mellow chocolate bitterness, herbs, citrus, earthy, pineapple, alcohol, soy sauce, raisin, licorice, coriander, peppercorn and coffee oil bitterness. AFTER TASTE: hop spice, roasted malt, coriander and dark stone fruit with an oily medium body finish followed by a spice/alcohol warmth.

Bottle. Orange-chocolate malt and grapefruit peel/pine aroma. Dark brown with moderate head light tan head. Sweet orange, light chocolate malt, and moderately bitter dry lemon peel flavor. Body on the lighter side. Not bad but light malt.

Bells The Planets series with Holst accompaniment.

Mahogany body with a thin, beige, soapy collar. Aromas of light spice, brown bread, malt, yeast. Bready, lightly sweet, mild alcohol. Pretty good.

On tap at Bells on 8/7/15. Black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of dark malts, grapefruit, tropical fruit and pine. Malty and piney flavor with tropical fruit and alcohol accents before a chocolatey and hoppy finish.

Black pour with a lovely herbal and floral/grapefruit nose with loads of black roasted malt. The flavor is intensely dark and toasty and roasty with a kiss of roast and molasses on top of the darkness, with loads of delightful west coast grape fruity/floral/piney hops. Amazing. Full and bitter and just the right amount of sweetness and char and floral resins.

Bottle. Mahogany beer with a dark tan head. Grapefruit and light darker malt aroma. Grapefruit and pine flavor with dark malts. Medium bodied. Grapefruit nd pine linger with light cocoa and dark malt.

Licorice, anise, and pine needle nose. Cola brown, medium tan head, good lacing. Licorice, cola, pine needle, intense but a tad too sweet. Strong charred oak finish. Medium to full body, resinous. Big and roasty, but off balance.

Bottle. Black pour with a medium, rocky and foamy brown head. Aroma is fruity with floral hops, tropical fruit notes and hop resins. Taste is chocolate, citrus, tropical fruit, floral hops and piney notes. Body is medium with a moderate carbonation and light lingering hop bitterness. Slightly oily as well. Ends with more chocolate, soft roasted malt, pine, citrus, tropical fruit notes, mint-like coolness and floral hops.
Dark brown, 1 finger head that faded to a thin line. Light aroma, chocolate aroma, faded like the rest of these. a little astringent, old fudge and a little raisin. not a very good one

12 oz. Bottle thanks to Willrunforbeer. Black color, flimsy head. Aroma is herbal and mild citrus with burnt molasses. 
Flavor is pretty much spot on the aroma. The bitterness is pretty substantial with a medium body. Bitterness lingers a amount after the swallow. Its respectable.

12oz bottle from trade with umich03jm. Thanks, Jason! Held on to these so I could do the whole series together. Pours coca cola brown with a beige head. Aroma is nice, dark chocolate, date, molasses. Flavor follows. A touch of char and pine bitterness on the finish.
Poured from bottle thanks Willrunforbeer for the Ratebeer Camp extravaganza. Pours dark black with a thin tan head. Aromas of grass citrus pine and fruit. Taste is nice full of citrus and hop.
A very nice hoppy black IPA, something I am usually not one to praise. Citrusy and piney, roasty, a bit of cocoa. Good stuff.

Pours jet black with a creamy tan head. Aromas of dark malts with a nice forward resin/hop undertone, with bursts of citrus, tangerine and tropical fruits. Taste is malt at upfront but fades to the citrus hops, which linger nicely. Almost no alcohol notes; surprising in a beer at 9.5%. Nice offering.

On tap a tMaduro pre 2015 GTMW event, pours pitch black with a thick off white head, almost tan like, the flavor has a very nice citrus and dank front end with a good mixture of malt and sweetness as well, the flavor has a super hoppy front end with a smooth and light finish, not overly roasty but still balanced, nice stuff.

bottle, from State of Beer, Raleigh. ggod aroma, roasty citrusy. dark malts and some grapefruit. dark orangy brown color, good head andf lace. bitter flavor. medium body, creeamy smooth mouthfeel, bitter sweet finish. really like the flavor and finish. well done
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Bottle. 5/24/15 bottle date. Appearance: Black, opaque, and a thick creamy khaki foam cap with nice lacing. 
Aroma: Slight roast undertone with a strong hop aroma that is fruit forward, like tropical and berry notes, with pine resin as well. 
Taste: Starts with a rich, chocolate maltiness that has a slight hint of roast, quickly turning to a strong, but balanced resinous bitterness. Maltiness drowns out any fruity hop flavors. So smooth and drinkable for a beer of this strength and bitterness. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body with a moderate to high carbonation, especially for the style. 
Finish: Touch of roast of chocolate linger with some hop resin on the tongue. 
Overall: Probably the most balanced and drinkable Black IPA Ive ever had. has a rich maltiness that is not interrupted by sharp hop flavors. Considering its a double IPA, its all the more impressive.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark brownish black pour with khaki colored head, aroma brought notes of lots of pine, orange, grapefruit notes into a nice cocoa powder, dark chocolate note with some slight roast but pretty mild, some slight dark fruits. Taste was a mix of orange, grapefruit, pine, some slight orange juice into bitter roast, coffee, and a nice sweet cocoa note, finishing fairly bitter, slightly sweet.

Tallahassee. Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Dark brown leading to black, khaki colored head. brief lacing. Aroma has a nice roasted essence to it with some light coffee notes, just a hint of spruce. Flavor is full and bold with some coffee notes, a touch of citrus bitterness, some licorice notes. an overall roastiness permeates the back end. Mouthfeel has a nice full crispness to it. Pretty solid.

The beer pours very black with a small khaki-colored head. The aroma blends citrus and resin hops, astringent booze, and low levels of roast, and the taste is quite bitter with strong resinous and grassy hops dominating the tongue. The citrus flavors do bring a slight sweetness to the taste, but its not enough to cut through the roast bitterness that arises in the middle of the flavor on top of the hops; the aftertaste fades to hop flavor without too much roast remaining. The palate fuses a thick texture, medium body, and a soft carbonation.

12 ounce bottle purchased at Holiday Wine Cellar ($2.99). Pours black with a little bit of brown around the edge and two full fingers of creamy dark tan foam. AROMA of dank hops, tropical fruit, wet pine forest, light chocolate, grapefruit, and some grassy/earthy hops. FLAVOR has lots of juicy tropical fruit, sweet citrus, and notable dark roastiness and sweet-ish caramel/toffee as it approaches the finish. Much more fruity and sweet than most Black IPAs, and it works here. The high ABV is very well concealed, making this surprisingly quaffable. Somehow the sweeter fruity elements do not clash with the roasty elements here, and the result is certainly one of the best for this style that I have experienced. (113, 976)

Pours this dark black unclear with a creamy beige head. Aroma is big nice piney hops, roasted malts, and a tad of smokiness. Flavor brings balanced piney hops and roasted malts so smooth on the palate with a light creamy body.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Appearance is full inch of rocking mocha head, and very dark black. Aroma is grapefruit piney bitterness, a very sweet IIPA. Taste is sweet and rounded with some bitterness and roasts. Just a very well put together beer. Palate is well rounded not too bitter or roasty. Id drink this every day if allowed.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is a blend of syrupy sweetness, pine and candied grapefruit rind with some carob-like malts peaking through. Taste is an almost perfect blend of chocolatey malts, heavy pine and sweetness right off the bat. Grapefruit flavors arrive in the mid leading to a substantially bitter finish. Really good and agreeable black IPA!

12oz brown bottle from Whole Foods, into a nucleated schooner glass. It poured an opaque black colour, reddish at the edges when held to the light, with tight beige foam, long-lasting with lots of lace. Surprisingly well-balanced for a 9.5% ABV black IPA. Undeniably hoppy, but not too bitter which I enjoyed. Citrusy, earthy, woodsy, hint of lemongrass and Fruit Loops cereal. Equally complex in the malt department: toasty, roasty, hints of black cherry, black plum, black currant, black raspberry. Light-medium body, moderate carbonation. No adverse alcoholic traits despite the high ABV, though I definitely felt its warmth a minute later as my face reddened. Though the brewers boasts about the debittered black malt, I actually tasted plenty of charred grain qualities akin to porter and stout, in a very good way. Delicious bittersweet and fruity aftertastes. This is much how I imagine historic India Porter mustve tasted. Great stuff. Take it slow or itll kick your butt.
Bottle. Whoa - this is a good one! Extremely dark fairly dense pour with a dense khaki head. Citrus and roast, some molasses. Fairly dense palate. Awesome.
I wont buck the trend while rating this. It gets high marks for a reason. Its pretty damn good.

A very interesting brew, this beer is as deceiving as a magician. It leads you to expect malty flavors like a stout or porter but alas it is full of hoppy goodness true to the ale that it is. More complexity awaits the palate with subtle chocolate and light malts on the finish. This is a savory concoction. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very clean and pretty opaque charred wood pour. Two fingers of dark tan head. Nice aroma, woody and a little earthy from the dark malt. Notes of dry citrus rind and bright leafy hops. Flavor shows woody hops and earthy grain with a dry and citrus rind like bitterness. Citrus pith and floral/fruity hops. Medium light body with some alcohol.

New Beer Distributors, NYC bottle ($2.50): Pours black with a creamy, white head. Aroma is relatively light roast, way more fruitiness of the tropical variety, mostly mango it seems to me. I didnt get that much pine or herbs like some other people. The first and last sips of this beer gave me goosebumps. Maybe it was because I have not had beer in three days (weird). Anyway, it seemed to me to be way more of a DIPA and the roast was just something to accentuate the DIPA flavors. Those were good, of course, but I felt a tad underwhelmed by this beer. The fruit flavor was spot on, but I was a little confused about what it was doing with the roast and malt. It might just be me losing an understanding of this style.

Dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, toffee, hops, & fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel/toffee, molasses, pine hops, chocolate, and citrus/fruit; Finish is fairly bitter; Very nice.

Bottle @ home, thanks to jcnielsen for sending! Pours a black appearance with a lasting, two finger, dark brown head. The aroma is a combination of pine (earthy / herbal hops), tropical fruit (mango, pineapple, orange), and mild roast. The hops are nice in the nose and more fruity than is typical of a black ipa. Initially a nice mouth feel but it is a little astringent. Theres a dueling flavor of chocolate/roast/mild smoke to complement the tropical fruit and herbal elements. Strong and kind of boozy. Not super easy to drink due to the strength but fairly enjoyable. Id maybe give it another shot but Id like to see a lower abv level to make it easier to drink.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter.

Uranus pours black with a thick frothy dark tan brown head that lasts a long while. The aroma is pine, citrus, chocolate and wood. The flavor is citrus and pine up front with wood and chocolate lingering in the background. Uranus is medium to thick bodied, quite smooth and very drinkable. Overall this is a delicious beer and a great representation of a black double IPA.
Draft. Pours black. Aroma and taste are pine, roasted malts, citrus, and chocolate.

12oz bottle in a taster. Pours very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of floral and piney and bitter hops, some pale and dark malts, and some dough. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. Not the greatest beer.

Bottle. Stupid series beer. Guess its the Petey Completey in me. Nose us fruity, light soap, bitter cocoa. Taste is a bitter, astringent chocolate covered hop cone. Better as it warms shows more citrus and malt sweetness. Overall an actually decent and enjoyable beer from a style I loathe.

It pours black with a full, brown head. It has citrus aromas with roasted elements and a hint of chocolate. I has citrus and roasted malt and chocolate flavors that are balanced. It has a bitter finish.

Pours black with a tan head. The aroma has roasty stoutish malt, funk, green onions, dankness and some tropical fruits. It has a medium / full body with soft flowing carbonation. The flavor starts with pine, wood, mango, roasty malt, tropical fruits, dankness and some resin. The finish has heavy roast thats very stout-like. Quite nice.

Black pour with a two finger, creamy tan head that has great retention, being sustained somewhat by a surprisingly high effervescence, leaving a decent bit of lacing as it goes. Aroma is dark caramel, toasty chocolate, toasted nuts, dark toffee, sweet cereal, lemon and orange citrus, pear, guava, passion fruit, light melon, toasted nuts, sweet white bread crust, orange slice candy and light fruity floral notes. Flavor is roast, dusty chocolate and a hint of burnt sugar starting off, sweet and bitter citrus, light dankness, cooked melon, caramel, sweet and lightly resinous pine, papaya, grilled stone and tree fruit. Medium to heavy body, light, blanketing carbonation, creamy entry, off dry, still mostly creamy finish. Pretty tasty stuff overall, it hit many of the right notes, but the hops could stand to be a little more up front in the flavor.
Dark black. Dank. Subtle mango. Citrus. Starts off like a double IPA and rounds out to chocolate aftertaste. Some stout characteristics. Thx Vyvvy.
Bottle. Pours an opaque dark black with a thin layer of beige head. Aroma and taste of super roasted malts, some hoppiness.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with light beige head. Aroma is chocolate, roast, faint coffee, earthy hops, some dark fruit notes, faint ash, and faint burnt toffee. Flavor is dry and rich with notes of dark chocolate, espresso, earthy hops, and prunes. Medium body.
Uranus smells great. Credit to my wife for coming up with that. True though. Great double black IPA.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a light tan head. Citrus pine aroma with roastiness. Flavor is roasty cocoa and creamy with piney and citrus hops coming more on the back end. More stouty than some other Black IPAs, but quite good.

Thx H! Pours a very very dark cola brown with a foamy tan head. Aroma
has caramel, some chocolate and some citrus. Later it gets a bit
more roasty, and some pine shows through too. Taste is of roast, light
nut, chocolate, caramel and citrus. Medium bodied, smooth and lightly
oily in texture. Finishes well blended between roasty bitter and sweet
malty, with just a tinge of hoppy bitterness. This has some parts
but didnt think it came together too well. Not as hoppy for style as
expected. Perhaps a bit more aging? 13.6

Pours a dark brownish black from the bottle with fluffy tan head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma of resinous citrus hops and hints of earthy mint with an overlying dark chocolate note. Taste follows, big hop presence that immediately falls to the malty backbone. Mild bitterness, soft carbonation, alcohol is well hidden. Definitely one of the best in the series so far.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle. 

Opaque dark brown with a 3-finger khaki head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of pine, grapefruit, mango, orange, passion fruit, molasses and roasted malt. 

Taste of grapefruit, mango, passion fruit, pine resin, peach, roasted malt and molasses. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Dark pour with a tan head. Mostly pine and malt nose. Some citrus and pine in the taste, but certainly in the back seat to roasted malt, chocolate and finishing on the sweet side. Kind of a black barleywine.

Bottle. Obsidian looking pour, thin off-white head. Nose is pine and citrus. Mouth is medium-full, some roast notes punctuating a hopped up dark malt backbone with some cocoa and coffee hints. Not a huge Black IPA fan, and this one is average at best, but the series was worth it if for the Saturn alone. Side-note: this is my 1000th rating! Id like to send a shout-out to all those brain cells Ive killed and liver cells Ive damaged in the process. Heres to another thousand boys! 😎

Dark and complex smell that is slightly and a touch of hot alcohol, taste is complex and not nearly as hoppy as I would have thought, smooth, not too hot from alcohol either, gets more bitter and poorer taste with time... Palate looses subtlety... Drink slowly
12oz bottle. Poured a black color with an off white head. Pine, roast, floral hops, citrus, and chocolate. Alcohol content hidden.

Blackity black, light head. Aroma of hops and sweet chocolate malts. Taste is hoppy with flavors muted by dark malts. I feel like there are a lot of good hops but with all the dark malt its hard to distinguish, but you know its hoppy and this is a pretty good double black ipa Clean finish.Lots of good flavors going on.

Draft. Poured dark brown color with a large frothy tan head that lasted and produced excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy complex dark malt and hop and soft alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy dark bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a solid beer.

Pine resin and grapefruit standout in the aroma with a hint of mango and passion fruit and some graham cracker. Tastes of clementine up front, followed by brown sugar, then pine resin comes forward. Very good texture, fizzy, light, thick. Overall, very good.
Bottle. Dark, sweet malty nose. Full body. Nice charred molasses note with a very mild hoppy note. A unique quality to this one.

Bottle from craft ale house. Pours black with a medium sized tan head. The aroma has a good bit of dark chocolate, roasted malt, piney notes. The taste has a big bitter cocoa, light bitterness, a bit of citrus, piney hops. Well done 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep black-brown, with smallish head. Aroma includes some citrus notes, with a ton of roasted grain, some dark fruits, chocolate. Flavor is very hoppy--more so than most black IPAs Ive tried. Some chocolate, coffee, roasted grain, leather, and dark fruit in the background, but this is foremost a very citrusy, piny, bitter beer, ruled by its hops. The alcohol content is very well-hidden in this one. Very nice.

Leans more on the IPA side than the stout side but still well balanced. Big citrus with light roast and a hint of chocolate. Some caramelized malt. Medium bitter finish. Thick creamy consistency. Black pour with great mocha head and lacing. Bottle.

12oz bottle. Deep unfiltered opaque brown-black body. Massive fluffy, steady beige head. Pretty solid beer. The hops work here, having some nice depth while also displaying some cool new school mild tropical tones. The aroma has a hint of licorice among the roasty chocolate and crisp, almost spearmint hop nose. A big, full bodied beer. Impressive and not gimmicky. Lingering sweetness and bitterness. Bold and well executed.
Pours dark brown / black color with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and citrus. Roasted malt and chocolate flavors with citrus and pine. Medium body with average carbonation.
12 ounce bottle. Pours almost black with a decent tan head. Aroma of pine, citrus, and malt. Taste is citrus, tropical, pine, roasted malt, and a bit of chocolate. Very good.

Dark black with no seeing through. Thin off white head. Aroma of pine needles, with black malts displaying caramel and molasses beneath. Extremely drinkable. Palate is near perfect and abv is not noticable. Very good.

12oz bottle pours a dark brown/black with Amber highlights and a huge khaki head. Big scotch tape pine hop aroma, faded, mellow backing dark malt. Taste similar to aroma, just kinda bland and not exciting. Not bad but, just boring. Nothing here really stands out, neither the hops or malt profile.
Bottle. Pours a black color with khaki head. Piney, resiny aromas with a slight roasty backbone. Roasty, syrup, piney, resiny, chocolate syrup flavors. Good black ipa, I didnt notice the 9.5% abv
Pitch black, pine cone, pine needles, dark grape nose. Burnt cookie nose. The pine is off the charts on the palate. Feels smooth and yet chalky. A true hop bomb for a Cascadian.
From a 12 oz bottle courtesy of Ryan. Pours a clear dark cola with a tan head. Light asphalt aromas. Flavors of leather and citrus. Bitter roast finish.

Very enticing roast and citrus aroma, pours an opaque black with a thick light tan head. The beer starts off with a touch of roast and chocolate before the hops come through. Lots of tropical fruit and citrus notes, fading to a long lasting bitterness. Theres just a slight touch of astringency, which works with the beer. This is very light in body, especially for the (well hidden) high ABV. This is an outstanding beer.

Cant believe Im about to say this, but Bells is sooo inconsistent...hit and miss. Have had a ton of misses of late. This one fits the bill. Coca-Cola pour with a soapy eggshell head. Minimal roast, maximum bright bitterness and enamel-peeling citrus. Fruity, loads of evergreen, and grassiness. Yum.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a brown black with a sudsy khaki head that fades. Has a good mix of roasted malt chocolate and bitterness, nice bitterness. Some chocolate citrus pine coffee really like this mix very well balanced.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown color, but not black, with a creamy tan head. Aroma has a pleasant floral piney character. Flavor has a light roasted malt backbone with a decent floral, citrus, piney hop presence. Lighter in body for the color and pretty true to the style. Not a bad offering from this series.

This is almost the perfect blend of Porter/IPA. Very dark pour and tan head that leaves good lacing down the glass. But the aroma is not quite good, almost barnyard. With a bit more toasted malt flavor it would be perfect.

12oz bottle from Downer Wine and Spirits. Pours a deep, dark brown color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is hoppy, fruity, orange, pineapple. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, bittersweet chocolate, hops, orange, pine, some grapefruit, some light bready sweetness on the backend, with a light, bitter pine finish.

Bottle. Dark black pour, a little thin lasting carbonation and an aroma of nice earthy orange citrus. Flavor is also nice peaty citrus, pears and good and piney on the aftertaste. Definitely unique and worth picking up.

I may need to update my review after I have another one, but more cold. I let this one get a bit warm after pouring (got distracted by something) and Im thinking it will be better colder. Poured very, very dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is roasted grain and some citrus hops. Taste is dark roasted malt, more subdued than I was expecting citrus and pine hops (more citrus) and just a tad of booze. Very well balanced, and not as warming as I was expecting based on the taste. Pretty highly carbonated, which detracts some from the beer. Darn good black DIPA.
Bottle. Pours thick and rich black with 2-finger tan head that laces well. Nose is dark malt, heavy resiny hops. Tastes piney, hoppy, with roasty dark malt, a very smooth palate, and good balance.

Dear Bells: please make more of this. Dark brown pour with light brown head. Piney grapefruit citrus aroma. Slightly chocolaty up front, bitter grapefruit pine hop. Emphasis on the pine, long lingering piney finish. Close your eyes and its a very bitter strong DIPA, open them up and your brain allows you to sense the hints of cocoa. Great example of my current favorite style of beer.
Not a big fan of black ipas but this one knocks it out of the park. Great aroma great taste.
Piney aromas, roasty. Black with a fairly lasting beige head. Dry, earthy hops, coffee flavors. Medium bodied.
Fresh juicy hop and crisp citrus aroma.off white head and dark black body. Roasty malt and light fresh hop flavor with light piney citrus notes. Crisp and refreshing on the palate.

June 26, 2015 - bottle from Blue Max. Black pour with nice amount of head. Aroma was roasted malt with citrus and piney hops. Taste was more sweet malt than roasty with a mild citrus and piney bitterness.

12oz bottle. Black pour with small tan head and lacing. Aromas are very united, pine, roasted woods, caramel, Creamy palate. Mild sweetness with well blended flavors of pine, roasted malts, with subtle chocolates and coffee. Bitterness takes a back seat. Very easy to drink. I would buy this if it was easy to get.

Of course Uranus is black. Its got a nice hop aroma, but its not as clear as the Hopsolution from the robustness of the malt. Finish starts off dark malt bitterness and glides into hop bitterness. Nice beer.

12 ounce bottle - $2.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a black body with a slowly, albeit steadily growing beige-hued head. Lovely lacing.

Smell: Floral and piney as well as fairly citrusy with the hop notes floating atop the black malts hinting of creosote and burnt coffee.

Taste: Sweetish, roasty malts with some chary, bratty astringent accents to it, and slight underscores of chocolate, coffee and toast. Citrusy, with a lemony/grapefruity vibe and touches of dried, grassy herbs. Medium bitterness. A little heat from the alcohol. Drying, hoppy, harshly roasted finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Not bad, better than expected.

Pours black with a frothy tan head. Aroma is big tropical fruits, pineapple, citrus and dank pine resin. Creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is up front citrus hops with roasted malt. The roasted malt has no bitter roasted flavors. Followed by pineapple and sweet citrus orange flavors. Right before finish is chocolate flavors. Finishes with grapefruit and dank smoky pine resin. Some light roasted flavors in finish. Fantastic!
Well done black IPA. No tobacco or chocolate to interfere with the well-managed blend of malt, hops and a curiously light fruitiness that hits about mid-palate. Sweet and dangerously drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a dark caramel brown with a solid two finger off white head with excellent lacing. The scent is a mix of citrus hops, cocoa, and licorice. The taste is citrus, coffee, chocolate, and black licorice. Excellent offering that finishes dry with a creamy full mouthfeel.

Bottle to snifter. Pours black, tan foam head fades quickly. Not picking up anything special on the nose. Good carb, body, pretty straight forward black IPA, nothing wrong with that.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. The pour is black. The aroma is all hops, but not over powering. The taste is good, but kinda boring overall. Bitter hops is the best way to describe it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Gentiles. Poured black with thin beige head. Aroma sweet hoppy pine roast. Light carb med bod. Tastes semi bitter choc dank

6/19/2015...  Aroma of semi-sweet chocolate and some piney hops; pours a really dark brown texture and is quite opaque; flavors of caramelized malt, dried fruits, tropical and pine hops; moderate bitterness and very balanced overall; Medium full body with slick, oily texture; alcohol well hidden; perfectly drinkable, but too smooth or homogonous or something... some roasted maltiness, ground coffee, or dark chocolate bitterness would have been nice to cut the malty sweetness. Don?t get me wrong, this is a really good beer, but put Bell?s, Limited Edition Series, and Double Black IPA on the label and it instantly becomes overhyped and overpriced... aldo, I hate the term dank!

Bottle 355ml @ ChurchKey, Washington, DC
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, citrus, orange and hint of alcohol and chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, malty, citrus and orange finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville 6/12/15. Clear dark brown, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of piney, herbal hops, mild chocolate, clay and roast. The taste is stone fruits, citrus and tropical hops, sugared fruits, mild roast. Medium bodied, mild lingering bitterness.

Bottle at Church Key, DC. A dark brown beer with a small, dense dark beige head. Some lacing. Some roasted malts in the aroma, with a nice piney, resiny and grapefruity hoppy touch. Its lightly roasted in the flavor, with roasted notes, some dark chocolate and coffee and with a nice bitterness. Some pine cones. Lasting finish. Quite nice this one, but Id like it more pronounced. 150620

Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head but lots of lacing. Nose is dank hops with a little chocolate. Taste is nice dank and citrus with a little roast. Definitely balanced towards the hops. Alcohol burn in the aftertaste. Probably the best of the Planet series.
Bottle. This is a nice roasted hop bomb of an IPA. Really well crafted and executed.

bottle that poured dark brown with off white head that lasts a good long time. nice lacing on the glass. excellent blend of mild roasted malts along with a nice citrus hop aroma. also a real mild chocolate blend as well. the flavor is more of the same. mild flavors of chocolate and roasted malts, plenty of citrus hops mild bitterness and just a touch of pine on the end. overall this is an excellent beer. should find some more of these.
Hops and roasted malts on the nose. Pours like a Coca Cola. Roasted malts, citrus hops and coffee with some alcohol heat. Pretty darn good.

Roasted malt aroma with cocoa and a nice floral hop aroma. Taste is a dark malty IPA, mostly floral hops but some piney bitter in the finish, but the roasted malt balances the bitter hops nicely. Still on the bitter side but nice. Smooth balanced and full flavored. A bit more bitter than I usually like but with the dark toasty malt and slight sweetness form the malt it really works. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown pour with an off white almost khaki head and striped lacing .... Aroma is of citrusy hops, tropical fruity and roasted malts ... Lightly piney ....,, taste is of roasted malts, dark chocolate and bitter piney/citrusy hops ..... Comes off slightly oily in the mouthfeel ... Has a lingering bitter dry hopped and roasted finish .... Solid black IPA smells hop forward but flavor wise more on the back end.
12oz bottle - pours a dark brown . Floral aroma with hints of roast . Taste is similar with some pine . Tasty .
bottle. Black with one finger head. Very malty base with medium hops. Pretty mild bitterness. Not as hop forward as I expected. Still, great flavor. Light booze.

Sampled from a bottle, 
this ale had a dark brown-black pour and gave a one to two finger light tan and tan colored head that receded to a film layer with open areas and ring, 

the aromas were intense toasted malt and some roasted malt, citrus hops, some coffee and chocolate with a little malt and brown sugar sweetness, 

this drink had an intense toasted and roasted malt with grapefruit citrus and spice hops, coffee and chocolate with a little caramel and brown sugar sweetness, 
the finish had a hop bitterness with a little malt bitterness and roasted malt trailing afterwards, the bitterness lingered on the tongue for a moment or two, 

the mouth feel was medium with some creamy feel and the carbonation was average, 

the flavor was bigger and better than the nose, the aromas were weak a first but came out a little as it warmed up, the flavor had more hops and malt than the nose, a nice black IPA.

Draft, Wow, this is a special one, aroma is citrus and roasted malts... Taste is a huge amount of citrus and tons of roasted malts and coffee, a touch of soy... So good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours black with an off-white head that leaves significant lacing behind after a few sips. Wonderful tropical fruit aroma, some citrus; I cant detect any roasted malts in the nose. The taste is similar; lots of fruity hops. This is really a black IPA for a hop head who normally doesnt care for black IPAs. Medium bodied, average carbonation, lightly bitter finish. My favorite of the Planets series thus far.

Bottle. Pretty much black, opaque, thick brown head with good retention and solid lacing. Smells like Christmas dipped in chocolate. Taste is earthy, sweaty pine needles and fresh fruit rolled in cocoa powder and black pepper then dipped in dark chocolate. Holy cow.

Poured into a Spiegelau glass balck with a huge tan head.
Aroma is sweet bitterness some light roastiness.
Flavor is so beautifully DIPA with a coffee vanilla kick. 
Smooth and no over the top roastiness of some sub Black IPAs.
Thinking this is my fave of the planet series.

12 oz bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Black with 1-2 fingers of light tan head. Aromas of pine, citrus, chocolate and roast. Tastes of pine, floral notes, dark chocolate, roast. Medium body with a dry finish. No alcohol noticeable for 9.5%. Pretty damn tasty.

Bottle:
Pours black, with a large, frothy, light tan head.
Coffee roast, licorice, chocolate aroma.
Taste is sweet, dark malts, chocolate, coffee, vanilla.
Big, resiny/grapefruit peel bittering.
Creamy...
Excellent !!!

12 oz. bottle. Pours a rich, dark brown with a medium tan head. Good lacing. Aroma of tropical fruit and citrus hops, and mild chocolate notes. Flavor is smooth, fruity, with medium chocolate flavor. This beer avoids astringency and bitterness that are typical of black IPAs. Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Finishes hoppy and fruity. Nice.

12 oz. bottle at Keystone-Clifton, poured into a tulip. Pours a mostly cloudy dark brown with lighter, clear deep amber edges and a centimeter or so of beige head that settles into a ring. Really nice balance throughout this - chocolate, tobacco, mild roast, citrus and also some tropical fruits, pine, earth, florals, and - the most interesting aspect to me, and one that became more pronounced as it warmed - coconut. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a bitter, sweet, fruity, and spicy mouthfeel where none of those four characteristics drowns out another. I really enjoyed this one; definitely the best of the series so far.

Pours a deep dark brown to black with a decent khaki-cappuccino head that hangs out a while and leaves a soapy wall and collar of lace. Nose involves dark chocolate, bbq smoke, woody and earthy hops, some stone fruit and marmalade underneath. Decently sweet, quite bitter. Medium to full bodied, oily, tannic, with a drying roasty finish. Good but tame on the hop profile. The smoke element makes up for that, however, making it drink like a hoppy, smoky imperial porter.

12 ounce bottle poured into a brandy snifter. The aroma has big citrus notes and is also a bit piny. The taste is much the same. My first thought when I started drinking this beer was that if I was blindfolded, i wouldnt be able to tell this was a black ipa. I didnt pick up on any of that roasty, or ashy charafter i get out of so many other black ipas. Truly a unique beer.
Tropical fruits and bubblegum aromas. Taste is of pine hops, pineapple, roasty malts, and booze.

12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Bottled 5/21/15. Out of the whole series, Ive been looking forward to this one most. Clear, but very dark brown, slightly red color. Nice finger of tan head. Leaves nice ridges of lace along the side of my tulip-style pint glass. Up front in the nose, fantastic big citrusy and tropical hop, as well as a very unique dark malt note, like some kind of winter spice, gingerbread or muffins or something, some brown sugar... Taste is moderate-plus sweet, kind of a spicy bite to it. Moderate bitter. Great aroma, but... Significant spicy bite to this. Bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Very lightly slick, touch dry in the finish. Chocolate, grapefruit citrus. Definitely some tropical aroma. Touch of coffee. Mild nuttiness, and cake-like malt. No doubt, an amazing aroma. A very interesting and complex black IPA. The sweet bite just slows me down, though. Its kind of a strange brew. The front is so complex and welcoming. But sips are punished with a rough and regretful backend. Like a vice, though, you find yourself repeatedly lifting the glass for more sips. The initial pleasure makes the unpleasant aftereffect repeatedly bearable. I was glad to have a 12oz all to myself, but I wouldnt want to do any more than that.

From a bottle into a snifter. Black opaque with a large light brown head. Nice hop nose with pine, some fruit, roasted malts, hint of anise. Medium body, high carbonation, medium sweetness, high bitterness. Intense flavors here, lots of dark malt flavors lingering on the palate with anise, burnt coffee, pine tar, hints of fruit. Lots of intense, pleasant flavors here just not sure they all work together nicely.
Best of series so far? Deep brown with minimal head. Aroma is pine, pineapple, gradefruit, dank malt. Taste is roasted ipa. Very enjoyable.

Look - Very nice tan head with sticky lacing. Dark body. Bubbles are thick. 

Smell - It isnt DIPA dank, but the dank grapefruit is there. Pineapple. Very little chocolate and coffee. 

Taste - Terrific. Chocolate comes through in the taste. Dank citrus. 

Feel - Medium to full bodied. Smooth and creamy. No carbonation bomb. 

Overall - Maybe I just like Black IPAs but this is great. Mad Tree Identity Crisis was my first taste of the style. It is not a hoppy stout/porter. It is much better! Dank!
355ml bottle. DArk brown pour with a large off-white head. Aroma is cocoa and pine. Flavor is smoky, cocoa, pine, cool mint some fruits. A solid black ipa.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Its kinda thin looking as it pours. Aromas are heavy with chocolate and roast with just a hint of floral and oranges. Flavor has a lot of dark and heavy malts with some residual sweetness and a decent hops presence that is donated by tropical and citrus. Interesting take on the style with a lot of roasty malt that drives the bus.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle poured to a Czech-pils glass at Lunar Brewing Co., showing a nearly opaque, black/brown color, with some ruby highlighting, frothy to cakey, brownish tan head foam, and sheet-like cling to the lacing. The nose was soft grain, roasted mocha notes, citrus, with a touch of resin. Medium+ bodied, amped by decent carbonation, and a touch of creaminess to the mouthfeel, the taste also offered a moderate but lingering, roasted, earthy, citrusy, and rind-like bitterness that was also calmed a bit by the creaminess. Nice roast & IPA balance.

Bottle to pint glass. Looks good; a translucent dark cola with light beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells of dark malt, dark chocolate, and loads of bitter and piney hops. Perhaps a bit of roast too, but I cant discern if its from the hops or malt. Tastes like it smells with a fairly bitter medium to medium full-bodied mouthfeel. Intense, but enjoyable.

Pours black with a thick tan head. Thick soapy lacing all around my tulip glass. Fantastic aroma. Not as resinous as I though it would be. Big tropical nose with a slightly dank, roasty note to it. Great tropical fruit flavor with a slightly roasty back end. Once again, not as resinous as I thought it would be. Hard to believe this is 9.5 ABV. Medium/Full bodied with a creamy/slick mouthfeel. Finish is very dry but not astringent at all. Obviously Bells has saved the best for last in the planet series. The last two have been fantastic. At 2.50 a bottle I would also say this is one of the best buys in beer.

Pitch black pour with mahogany hue and an eighth inch of khaki head, very small bubbles evident rising from the glass bottom. Aroma of oats and pre-beer grains, and a hint of chocolate. Average to lively carbonation, frothy creamy mouthfeel, dry finish that leaves film on teeth. Great blend of flavors: pine hops, Carmel malt, bitter chocolate, zesty citrus rind, a bit boozy. Pretty solid black IPA, reminds me of a two hearted with different darker malts.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Clear dark brew that glowers deep brownish red when held up to light. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit, hints of resin, toast and coffee. Taste is very slightly sweet malts and grapefruit up front transitioning to a toasty malt, slightly resinous grapefruity tropical fruit finish. A bit of roasted grain, coffee and cocoa emerges at the end. Excellent.
Pours black like a stout or porter with a thick tan head. Citrus and floral aroma. Taste follows the nose. No booziness comes through. Overall one of the better beers from this series.

12 oz bottle (5/24/15) poured into bells snifter--b-52s playing in background. Immediate and powerful hoppy aroma: mostly pine resin though fading to fruit deeper in the nose. The nose is recapitulated in the taste, though with pineapple in the ascendency more than pine resin. Medium mouthful--alcohol fairly well concealed. >a nice drive in the rain

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 5/24/2015. Pours fairly pitch black color with a 2 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, chocolate, cocoa, toast, light char/coffee, and floral/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate roasted malt notes; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, pine, chocolate, cocoa, toast, light char/coffee, and floral/grassy earthiness. Good amount of pine/charred bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, pine, chocolate, cocoa, toast, light char/coffee, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate roasted malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately sticky, and slightly creamy/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Black DIPA style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate roasted malt flavors; and very smooth to drink for the big ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Aromas are grapefruit, pine, tropical fruit, cocoa, dark bread, and light coffee. Tastes hoppier than the aroma suggests. Big citrus and tropical fruit, light floral and pine hops, and lots of dusty cocoa. Very dry finish. Not a fan of the mouthfeel, rough and chalky. I really thought I was gonna like this one but its just ok.
Cocoa powder and roasted coffee up front, balanced well with grapefruit bitterness and citrus peel. Undertones of toasted bread and brown sugar. Fairly dry citrus finish. All around very good.
Aroma of roasted malts and citrus hops, taste is citrus, chocolate, and some coffee, a fantastic black double ipa up there with some of the tops of the style , very good!
Aroma of pine and grapefruit, taste is sweet malt forward with a punch of great pine and grapefruit, dry finish. Very pleasant.

Quite a difficult beer to get, even here in Bells home territory. Pours out a dark nearly black liquid with huge citrus hops aroma which almost buries the black roasted components. Orange and grapefruit loom, with just a hint of tannic dark acidity. Intriguing and complex, with a touch of alcohol heat apparent in the finish.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate-heavy citrus and grapefruit with light chocolate. It pours a dark brown with some orange highlights and a one finger khaki head that quickly fades to a thin film outlined by a thicker soapy ring. There is a lot of thin soapy webbing left on the sides of the glass, The flavor starts with a quick dose of chocolate and light tropical fruits. The finish has moderate-heavy grapefruit and citrus. Its medium bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel. Overall, its tasty and tropical fruit flavors distinguish it a little from other Black IPAs, but Id still put it in the hoppy Porter category with most other Black IPAs.
